Lefthanders and Righthanderstime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputinput.txtoutputoutput.txtOne fine October day a mathematics teacher Vasily Petrov went to a class and saw therenpupils who sat at thedesks, two people at each desk. Vasily quickly realized that numbernis even. Like all true mathematicians, Vasily has all students numbered from 1 ton.But Vasily Petrov did not like the way the children were seated at the desks. According to him, the students whose numbers differ by1, can not sit together, as they talk to each other all the time, distract others and misbehave.On the other hand, if a righthanded student sits at the left end of the desk and a lefthanded student sits at the right end of the desk, they hit elbows all the time and distract each other. In other cases, the students who sit at the same desk, do not interfere with each other.Vasily knows very well which students are lefthanders and which ones are righthanders, and he asks you to come up with any order that meets these two uncomplicated conditions (students do not talk to each other and do not bump their elbows). It is guaranteed that the input is such that at least one way to seat the students always exists.InputThe first input line contains a single even integern(4 ≤n≤ 100) — the number of students in the class. In thei-th line print the numbers of students that will sit at thei-th desk. The first number in the pair stands for the student who is sitting to the left, and the second number stands for the student who is sitting to the right. Separate the numbers in the pairs by spaces. If there are multiple solutions, print any of them.ExamplesInput6LLRLLLOutput1 42 56 3Input4RRLLOutput3 14 2

You are given an even number of people, some of whom are left-handed and some right-handed.  You need to arrange them into pairs, sitting at desks, following these rules:

* People sitting together cannot have consecutive numbers.
* A left-handed person cannot sit on the left side of a desk with a right-handed person. 

Output a list of pairs, where each pair represents two people sitting at a desk.

You are given an even number $n$ ($4 \le n \le 100$) representing the number of students in a class.  Each student is either left-handed (L) or right-handed (R).  

You need to arrange the students into pairs, with each pair sitting at a desk.  The following rules must be followed:

* Students whose numbers differ by 1 cannot sit together.
* A left-handed student cannot sit at the left end of a desk with a right-handed student at the right end.

Output the pairs of students who should sit together at each desk.  There will be $n/2$ pairs.
